revisions.rev:
{{Infobox radio station | name = KKSN | image = | city = [[Vancouver, Washington]] | area = northern [[Willamette Valley]] and [[Clark County, Washington]] | frequency = 910 ([[kilohertz|kHz]]) | airdate = 1980 | branding = 94/7 too | slogan = Independent Radio | format = Local music (KNRK-HD2 simulcast) | power = 3,300 [[watt]]s day
4,300 watts night | class = B | facility_id = 35033 | coordinates = {{coord|45|33|30.00|N|122|28|57.00|W|region:US-WA_type:landmark}} | callsign_meaning = '''K'''i'''S'''si'''N''' | former_callsigns = KTRO (2007–2010)
KKSN (2005–2007)
KOTK (2004–2005)
KFXX (1998–2004)
KKSN (1980–1998){{cite web | url = http://www.fccinfo.com/CMDProEngine.php?sCurrentService=AM&tabSearchType=Appl&sAppIDNumber=25127&sHours=D | title = FCCInfo Results: KTRO(AM) | date = 2009-06-12 | accessdate = 2009-06-14 | publisher = Cavell Mertz & Associates, Inc. | work = FCCInfo.com | location = Manassas, Virginia }}
''(see also [[KISN (Portland)]])'' | owner = [[Entercom]] | licensee = Entercom Portland License, LLC | sister_stations = [[KFXX (AM)]], [[KWOD]], [[KGON]], [[KNRK]], [[KYCH-FM]], [[KWJJ-FM]], [[KRSK]]{{cite web | url = http://www.fccinfo.com/CMDProFacLookup.php?sLicensee=ENTERCOM%20PORTLAND%20LICENSE,%20LLC&tabSearchType=Licensee | title = FCCInfo Facility Search Results: Entercom Portland License, LLC | date = 2009-06-12 | accessdate = 2009-06-14 | publisher = Cavell Mertz & Associates, Inc. | location = Manassas, Virginia }} | webcast = [http://player.streamtheworld.com/_players/entercom/player/?id=KNRKHD Listen Live] | website = [http://www.947.fm/ 947.fm] | affiliations = }} '''KKSN''' is a commercial [[radio station]] licensed to [[Vancouver, Washington]], broadcasting to the [[Portland, Oregon]] and [[Clark County, Washington]] area on 910 [[AM Broadcasting|AM]]. KKSN is owned by [[Entercom]] and airs a local music format branded as "94/7 too" (simulcasting [[KNRK|KNRK-HD2]]). ==History== The 910 AM frequency signed on the air in 1939 as '''KVAN''' and aired a [[country music]] format in the 1950s. From 1959 to 1976, 910 kHz was used by station [[KISN (Portland)|KISN]], which during its tenure had a Top 40 format. KISN was shut down by the FCC in September 1976 after a political bias scandal.{{cite news |work=[[Portland Tribune]] |title=Time to kiss KISN goodbye, again |url=http://www.portlandtribune.com/news/story.php?story_id=117253009218677600 |first=Phil |last=Stanford |date=February 27, 2007 |accessdate=June 10, 2009}}{{cite web | url = http://members.tripod.com/gsmo/91.html | title = KISN AM 91-wonderful Tribute Page (1959-76) | | accessdate = 2009-06-14}} The current station, which came on the air as '''KKSN''' in 1980, has aired numerous formats, including [[classical music|classical]] and [[adult standards]] (as "Sunny 910"), from 1987 to 1998. From 1998 to 2004, it was [[sports radio]] station '''[[KFXX (AM)|KFXX]]''', which has since moved to 1080 kHz. 910 then switched to [[hot talk]] as '''KOTK''' ("Max 910") then in 2005 to [[oldies]] as '''KKSN''', picking up the oldies format after [[KYCH-FM|KKSN-FM]] 97.1 ("KISN-FM") flipped to adult hits as "Charlie FM". On February 15, 2007 KKSN 910 AM changed their call letters to '''KTRO'''; and on March 28, 2007, [[KTRO-FM]] changed their format to regional Mexican and changed their call letters to [[KRYP]], and the existing talk format continued on KTRO 910 AM. The station is owned by [[Entercom]] but was programmed by [[Salem Communications]]. The former program lineup ([[Dennis Prager]], [[Hugh Hewitt]], [[Laura Ingraham]], etc.) was similar to that found on other Salem stations throughout the [[United States]]. On January 5, 2009, the station switched to a simulcast of [[KWJJ]], an FM country music station. The [[local marketing agreement|LMA]] with Salem Communications expired.{{When|date=June 2009}} On May 1, 2009, KTRO switched to [[ESPN Deportes Radio]], a Spanish-language sports talk network.{{Cite news |first=James |last=Day |work=Statesman Journal |title=Area radio stations alter programming; Some of the talk shows on KFXX will be tough to receive for area listeners |url=http://www.statesmanjournal.com/article/20090504/SPORTS/905040349/1001/NEWS/Area+radio+stations+alter+programming |date=May 4, 2009}} On May 28, 2010 KTRO changed their call letters back to '''KKSN'''. The station dropped ESPN Deportes Radio on July 12, 2010 in favor of simulcasting the programming of [[KNRK|KNRK-HD2]], which airs music from local bands.{{cite news|title=Several Changes At KNRK|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/76393/several-changes-at-knrk|accessdate=June 9, 2010|newspaper=All Access|date=June 8, 2010}} ==Previous logo== {{Empty section|date=March 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{AM station data|KKSN}} {{Portland OR Radio}} {{Modern Rock Radio Stations in Washington}} {{Entercom}} [[Category:Radio stations established in 1980]] [[Category:Radio stations in Washington (state)|KSN]] [[Category:ESPN Radio stations]]
